slidelink.displaytext: 19 Action Research vs. Traditional Education Research

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on action research. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

By the end of the lecture, you will understand more about action research through the following topics:

• What is action research

• Benefits of action research

• Steps to conducting action research

• Reflection and dissemination

• Action research report formats

What is action research? Action research is

• Conducted by one or more individuals

• For the purpose of solving a problem or obtaining information

• In order to inform local practice, and it has

• Limited generalizability

You may often wonder what is the point of conducting qualitative research or action research since the target is a small set of students in a particular setting? Actually there are many practical applications of action research. The findings can provide immediate feedback to an issue in a classroom or recommendations to improve a learning environment. Other educators can replicate your study in their own settings. Your ideas may also spark more ideas for further studies. It’s worthwhile just for the immediate benefits to improve your classroom or school.

Action research brings practice and systematic inquiry together. It Involves a cyclical process of inquiry by practitioners through

• Identification of problems

• Planning

• Action

• Evaluation

Action research is also called classroom research and teacher research. The purpose is to improve teaching/learning.

There are many benefits in conducting action research.

First, it is beneficial for the practitioners leading the research, it

• Provides a solution to an identified problem

• Promotes a culture of learning, self-assessment, and reflection among practitioners—an enhanced model of professional development

Second, for schools and districts where action research occurs, action research

o Positions teachers as agents of change

o Can change the culture in a school

o Can create a system-wide mindset for school improvement

Third, the benefits go to the field of educational research. Action research

o Seeks to close the gap between research and practice

o Brings practitioners into the culture of research—expanding the community of researchers

o Leads to a new type of research knowledge, grounded in everyday practice

To conduct action research, you will,

First, identify a problem or research topic and set the problem or research topic in a theoretical context.

Second, make a plan for data collection

Third, begin to analyze data, if necessary, allow the question or problem to change as you collect data, and

Fourth, report the data and make your recommendations. Most important of all, develop an action plan for continuous improvement based on the findings.

Selecting a focus area is the first step in any kind of research. For action research, this often begins with school practitioners asking themselves, “What are the everyday problems I face in my practice?” Answering this question typically leads to a broad list of issues, including concerns about school culture, student academic performance, or parental support.

In selecting the research topic/problem, consider the following criteria:

• Topic should be something the practitioner would like to see changed.

• Topic should be something within the practitioner’s locus of control, for example, launching a new professional development initiative, starting a new advising strategy. These are all something an educational practitioner have control over.

• The practitioner should feel passionate about the topic. The process will be rewarding, but it takes time and energy.

Once the topic is selected, it is useful for the practitioner to engage in reflection. A series of questions can be used to focus on the sense perceptions of the problem using the ORID method.

• Objective questions: The first category of question calls on the researcher to describe the problem as objectively as possible. For example, how does the problem look in the classroom? When the problem occurs, what do you hear being said? The point is try to be as objective as possible.

• Reflective questions. The second category of question calls on the researcher to give an open reflective response to the problem. This include questions such as, “How does this problem make you feel?” or “What experiences do you associate with this problem?”

• Interpretive questions: The third category is for the researcher to attempt to analyze the problem with the goal of determining the cause. This include questions such as, “Why is this problem happening?” “What are the root causes?” “What other explanations might there be?”

• Decisional questions: The final step is to decide what possible action could be taken to resolve the problem. Here, questions include “What can I do differently?” “What are my next steps?” and “What actions are appropriate?” These questions are the basis of the “action” in action research.

There are many types of data for use with action research. You can collect data from:

• Log or research journal

• Field notes

• Checklists

• Conferences and interviews

• Video and audiotapes

• Data retrieval charts (visual organizer)

• Rating checklist (rubric)

• Students’ products or performances

• Surveys

• Archival data, web sites, class journals, and email

There are different ways for data analysis.

• Quantitative data: You can report, compare, and display the results, e.g., test scores, survey results, school records, checklists, etc.

• Qualitative data: You can look for themes and patterns from data such as field notes, observation, focus groups, journals, self-assessments, etc.

• The third way is to triangulate the data sources and draw conclusions

After data analysis, we are now discussing the plan for action.

• Usually there should be a summary of research questions and findings.

• The researcher will also recommend actions, including information such as

• Who is responsible? (e.g., Teachers, students, principals, parents, others)

• Who needs to be consulted, etc.?

• Who will collect further data?

• Time line, and the

• Resources necessary to carry out the action plan.

Action plan can be implemented at different levels:

• At Individual level, it’s for the improvement of individual teachers’ classrooms

• At team’s level, a network of teachers are working collaboratively for school improvement project.

• At school- or District-wide level, the plan is to engage all members of the particular level (e.g., elementary or middle school level) in a community wide research endeavor.

Reflection is an important part of action research. We ask questions such as

• What were the intended and unintended effects of your actions?

• What educational issues arise from what you have learned about your practice?

Dissemination is also an important part of action research. We share the findings and action plan through

• Professional conversations

• Professional presentations within the school or a professional conferences, and through

• Publications: Writing to publish the results often encourages deeper reflection.

There are different ways to report action research. The traditional approach is to start with an introduction, followed by literature review, methodology, research findings, conclusion and recommendations.
Alternatively, your subheadings can reflect on the specific interventions and data collection considerations. This format also includes a reflection and action plan.
The third format could focus on individual subjects under the research. This may work well qualitative research that focus on a small set of students.

How does action research differ from traditional research?

Action research

o Presents new ideas about practitioner/researcher roles

o Aspires to local relevance, not generalizability

o Presents new ideas about how research is created

o Presents new ideas about the relationship between theory and practice

• Theory informs practice which, in turn, shapes theory

You can see from this table action research differs from traditional research in many ways, including goals, sources of research questions, approach to context, literature review, instrumentation, sampling, design, data analysis, and dissemination. Pause your video to view a more detailed comparison in this table.

Here are a few criteria for Evaluating Action Research.

• Determine the motivation and involvement of the practitioner researcher.

• Look for consistency between the research question and the methodology.

• Look for whether multiple methods of data collection have been used.

• Confirm that there has been an emergent, cyclical process of research and reflection.

• Determine whether there is any external peer review.

In this video, we have learned different ways to conduct action research through the following topics:

• What is action research

• Benefits of action research

• Steps to conducting action research

• Reflection and dissemination

• Action research report formats
